ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Time management; staying on track
This is the senior essay course. It was largely independent study with your advisor.
Was able to really pursue a long-term project on a topic that I was passionate about with ample support from faculty and advisors.
I learned how to conduct a literature review, how to conduct my own survey, and how to write a coherent 50+ page text.
Self-guided thesis

This class taught me tangible skills, such as time management, organization, collaboration, and adaptation. Perhaps even more importantly, the discipline required to complete a project of this magnitude taught me a lot about myself, as I learned ways to help pick myself up out of a slump and stay focused on the task at hand.
I improved my ability to engage with research material both primary and secondary and think of my own arguments as they pertain to Ethics, politics and economics
Research and writing skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Responsiveness of the instructors
The workshops and Grad TAs were very helpful.

Strengths are that the course is really what you make of it and that you can work at your own pace in coordination with your advisor.
Weaknesses are that office hours were often booked full/that there was no clear structure to them. I think it would be better if office hours had a certain theme (discussing lit review, data analysis etc). at least once per week in addition to broader office hours.
Little to no structure or guidance, must be improved.

Strengths of this course include an instillment of discipline and perseverance necessary for completing a project of this magnitude. It also provided me with collaboration skills and increased my adaptability. As for weaknesses, since the EP&E major covers such a broad range of subject matters, it was difficult to zero in on a specific essay topic; however, this is not necessarily a weakness, but perhaps even a strength because it has the potential to help students become better at identifying issues for which they are most passionate to write about. It was admittedly quite challenging to find an advisor who aligned with my research interests, so I recommend actively striving to get to know the Professors in any courses which you think could one day be related to your potential writing topic and being proactive in reaching out to potential advisors early.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes bc major requirement

No obviously unless this is your senior essay. But it was exactly as expected -- largely independent study and work on the paper with your advisor. The Grad TAs were awesome and helpful along the way whether it be office hours or workshops or connecting us with resources or even reading drafts themselves.

Well if you're an EP&E major... yeah it's kind of required. A thesis just is a lot of work. Make sure you have a good advisor, and don't be afraid to send full drafts to the student thesis advisors. Everyone is really helpful!
I would recommend the semester-long senior essay if you have a clear idea and schedule for writing. The semester passes by faster than you may think!
Every EP&E major must write a thesis, but this course needs to be streamlined and organized.
Yes, it is a formative experience in which you will become a better writer and collaborator, while learning more about yourself in the process.
If you're an EP&E student, you have to write an EP&E thesis
